comments.commentBody: I teach a wide range of courses at a community college (my students are in programs ranging from trades to policing to health care to fine arts to traditional university academics), and every term I've taught so far, I've had at least one student with a normatively "unexpected" pronoun, either disclosed in a private conversation with me or announced during introductions. This term, I decided to give students a little profile to fill out and hand in, in addition to the usual verbal introductions. I included a question about pronouns, and received some preferences for "they" from some of the most cis-gender-appearing students I've ever seen--it was eye-opening, even for a gender-studies-phile like me! The question of gender is being more widely and deeply explored among the entire breadth of the college-age generation, more than you might think.

Having taught for many years in a community college, in a program culminating in RN licensure,  I am  less interested in students' gender expression (or class, racial or cultural identity) than I am in their showing up on time for class, reading assigned material, and participating in discussions.  Professional /vocational programs in healthcare are more about learning to focus on others and work collaboratively than about self-expression. In this discipline, classroom dialogue that emphasizes identity is a distraction, except if a student speaks from their gender/class/race to flesh out health disparities or population/ community health discussions.  Theater, art or gender studies programs are the ideal platform to express one's personal identity; it would seem silly to address one's  gender identity  in a chemistry class, for example,  it's just not germane.
Okay, here's your reply. I've been teaching Economics for thirty years, at four different schools. I've never heard of anything like this in any class.

This is a problem that doesn't occur that often, I think.  I guess students' introducing themselves in class is not practiced in most classes, and introducing themselves with pronouns is done in very few classes, but probably most gender studies classes.  Let's hear from people taking or teaching a wide range of classes.
Come to Toronto. We need more tourists!

"Each neighborhood has its own sound and rhythm".... There should be a piano on the bus with Lang Lang playing a musical tour through NY...Is that Gershwin I hear going by? or Berlin, Rogers, Was that Rachmaninov going round the corner??? Lang Lang on a moving stage for the enjoyment of NYC.

"I regard their baggage-trains as equivalent."....Clinton has made public 30 years of her tax returns public. Trump has refused to release a single year of tax returns. That by itself should tell you that they are not equivalent. I could mention Trump's four bankruptcies and three trophy wives. His casual use of slander and bigotry; his level of narcissism which by itself should disqualify him for public office, or that he seems to believe everything he says is true even when he said the opposite just yesterday. Basically any one who claims their baggage is even remotely equivalent would have a very hard time trying to rationalize their position using facts.
Martin, Never read your comment before I posted. Mind meld.
"It is beyond obvious what is going on here."....You mean like reporting facts?

and Elke
Trying to ease my AGITA, decided to do some cooking along with the puzzle.
Specifically, to STUFF some green and red peppers. Then I went to the Wordplay page, and there are my peppers, although I used ground meat and quinoa. Now I am convinced there is a camera hidden in my kitchen (the camera on my laptop is ducktaped ). My common sense says "BUSHWA"; learned a new word- hope I used it correctly.
Have STUFFED also cabbage LEAves , but never kishke.
Since Eider ducks make an occasional appearance, their down makes great PILLOW STUFF.
Thanks, TP, for expanding my vocabulary and thus STUFFING my brain. PS- there still is room for more, there are some LAcUNAE still.
So please keep the puzzles coming.

Maybe taking on a 3rd job or further reducing their lives to eat and sleep and zero social activities?

I been there, 3rd job, cut even weekly McDonald's trip with the kids!
Prosperity is just around the corner.  Just around the corner from the polling place.
I'd suggest that you actually read the article to find out.

Why just a month ago there were many articles about Republicans not wanting to raise the minimum wage, and how so many people live in the poverty level and earn a minimum wage. So the question is, how did so many of the impoverished minimum wage earners suddenly "climb out of poverty"?
Tell your son to look away and wear headphones to be distracted. Hypnosis may help. You can't give blood if you are not awake to respond to commands.

I used to faint at the sight of blood too, Susan. My therapist (a phobia expert) said blood is the only phobia in which you really DO faint (and not just feel like you will). He taught me to do this (which works!): When you get that slight, I'm-about-to-keel feeling, tense all your muscles immediately. That will make your blood pressure go up immediately, thus preventing fainting. Hold it like that for about 10 seconds, then release but not completely. Also, don't look! My heart hurts for your son, but I'm now a 3-gallon club blood donor, which I never dreamed possible.

Consider donating platelets. The procedure returns your red blood cells back to you.  I used to feel queasy after a whole blood donation but I rarely feel that way when I donate platelets. The procedure takes about 90 minutes & the cancer patients who receive your platelets will be grateful. I am 61 years old & have donated 80 times. The techs at New York Blood Services (especially Staten Island) are superb!

My very healthy 31-year-old son has been prohibited from giving blood because he's a fainter.  He's tried lots of things to prevent it, but nothing has worked well enough.  This has been ongoing ever since he passed out at the sight of his own blood from a cut on his head in my second-grade classroom.

"Looks like the Times is trying to manufacture good news for Hillary on the night before the debate. "....Hey, if you don't like the facts maybe you should just make up whatever you want to believe. Like global warming is a fraud, and the median income didn't really increase by 5.2% last year. And the monthly jobs reports are all lies. And inflation is high even though gasoline is half of what it was four years ago and the price of eggs and milk have fallen significantly. Or how about the bargain basement mortgage rate - that is probably all made up too.
Why should voters start worrying about that now after who they chose in the last two presidential elections. Look at the world mess and the failing U.S. Economy.
Are you referring to Hillary Clinton? I agree. She is crazy.
There's no reason to stoop to the GOP's tactics of remote diagnosis. He has enough, just with the dirt he is carrying, to be disqualified.

With  strong  schizophrenic personality traits, and his ever ready  succumbing  to dangerous xenophobic racist impulses that have mainly shaped his mental universe and behaviour, while  the reasons why Trump should be rejected by the voters are many but perhaps none to support him for the President. The voters ought to weigh the long term consequences of their voting act before making such a choice. For, it's not the US only but the whole world whose future is at stake in this unprecedented election of America in recent years.
If you want somebody to tell you what you want to hear better go listen to Fox News. If you want to know the facts, better find a different source.....and global warming is a liberal fraud.

@RLS: The next President will be either Hillary or Trump.  As a Bernie voter and still a fan, I would remind you that the primaries are over, finished, done with - period.  Let them go.  Since you were for Bernie, I assume you would not want Trump appointing the justices to the Supreme Court, but that's what you and others like you will end up with if you keep up this nonsense.

Better yet, rewrite this section of the US Code.  Requiring everyone to stand and put their right hand over their heart while the national anthem is playing is puerile. Are we all supposed to revert back to third grade when the national anthem starts to pay.  We can love the US without being jingoist.  Presumably, there are things that you would like to be a little different in the US, too, J.  There's nothing wrong with saying or signalling so.

Who is the true patriot? Kaepernick, the kneeler, who wants to make the country better for all? Or the likes of George W. Bush, the stander and saluter, who dragged this country into two unnecessary wars wasting thousands of lives and trillions of dollars?
I suppose Muhammad Ali should have looked for a real job, too. And we remember him as what - oh, yes, a gifted athlete AND an activist.

If they have the time and the money and the desire to protest, why don't they go down to the nearest military Recruiting Office and volunteer to shake the hands of the enlistees and the Recruiting Detail?  It would not require much time.  But it would require GUTS, which they seem to lack.....

It does not require anything. It does not define a crime.

The article you refer to clearly says "should" and does not define a crime not imposes any obligation.

You can easy idly find it online ...

You seem to be missing the heart of the subject.

The problem is the violence committed by representatives of the government against its citizens, by people who are vested by the government and are the only ones able to use legitimate violence against the citizens.

As such it is government sponsored violence. Any abuse of its power may be argued to be tyranny.

A pattern of systematic abuse of power by representatives of the state is quite a serious problem don't you think ?

But mostly, it is a subject, when the repetition of acts statistically show an institutional problem, where actions can be taken by the government to limit and correct this pattern.

The government can intervene to reduce these problem by better organizing, training, choosing, police force.

That does not make the subject of black on black violence irrelevant for example. But solving this other, eventually linked issue, asks for a solution that is broader than ensuring police forces do not show a pattern of potentially racist behavior through statistics.

Finally, you brandish as proof of your conclusions a part of the problem : the impunity of the police until now, when widespread personal videos contribute to establish a pattern that was before hidden through the systematic primacy of the police officers testimony about the situation they faced.

These overpaid athletes ALWAYS talk about having a "dialogue" about white racism.

WHEN is there going to get kneeling and fist raising to remember and have a dialogue about the thousands of innocent black people killed by other blacks>?

@CC ~ Please stop calling Hillary Clinton, The Anointed One. She has been a diligent hard worker and accomplished woman since her college days at Wellesley College (probably before that as well). You may not like her but she has worked hard to get this nomination. She began her quest in earnest in 2008 only to lose by a whisker to the charismatic Obama. The press did her no favors then and I am beyond impressed by her tenacity in trying to break through the highest glass ceiling that has until now been closed to women.
Do you realize how often you write in hyperbole? Or maybe it is intentional on your part to exaggerate and distort reality.

Han Han is refreshing, he rides through the journalistic probing gracefully never taking the offered bait. His generation is in a sense wonderful to watch as they like to say ‘we are getting richer’ meaning not more money but more exciting times more open doors and more understanding of what matters. Much the same is seem elsewhere for millenniums but a cloak of uncertainty as well. Wish them well.
His last paragraph by the way holds the core of debate on the route of International Relations for China in today’s world; he is more of an intellectual than he wishes to allow if you read Taiwan and Hong Kong as the world at large.

I personally could find a thing that has more contradictions in China, good choice

Though it is not relevant at all in knowing who buys it, it is the work that matters

Look again at Zeng Fanzhi’s picture heading the article and try to imagine its impact on the assorted viewers.
The red kerchiefs are found around the necks of early grammar school children, where they enlist in the pioneers and are given ‘the story’ of the peoples revolution and such.
One can never tell what an artist is thinking, but he might be having a little fun.
Would be interesting to know who buys that one, and why.
Hyperbole is not your friend.  Frying pan into the fire?
And yet, he is winning. How very frustrating for you, Rita.
Lies and more lies .Trump for President .

The Donald is America's quintessential chicken coming home to roost. He may be the ultimate price that must be paid for satiating Hillary's vanity needs. But it's a fair price because vanity is as draining of life as is crack cocaine.

Trump is unprepared, intellectually lazy, and inarticulate. But more importantly he seems emotionally unstable and unable to stay focused on anything other than himself. His rankings border on the manic.

The Republican Party should be ashamed that this man is their nomineee.
